newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa rand/bonds closing report.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa rand/bonds closing report.

text.p: The rand slid to a two-month low against the dollar shortly before the close on Monday on late buying interest and dollar short-covering, dealers said.
After spending most of the afternoon trading in a tight 4.56-4.5625 bid range, the rand fell to 4.5650 bid level against the U.S. unit -- its worst level since August 22 when it touched 4.5680.
"There was some late buying interest this afternoon and people were taking back their short (dollar) positions," a dealer said.
In after hours trade, the rand fell further to reach 4.5670 bid on the dollar.
The rand initially weakened in early morning dealings on offshore and local dollar demand and covering of short positions.
Dealers said the central Reserve Bank's presence was felt in market around the 4.5650 level.
"Around 4.5650 there were a lot of dollars on offer and it looked like their was some pressure from the (Reserve Bank) up north," one dealer said.
"Londoners were also selling dollars around this level, taking some profits," he added.
A lack of interest saw the rand spend much of the afternoon hovering around the 4.5610 bid level until the buying spurt in late dealings.
Dealers said they expected the rand to trade in 4.5525-4.5650 range on Tuesday, although the unit was seen spiking up if it broke above 4.5650.
"If it goes above 4.5650 we are going to see it higher," a dealer said, adding that offshore players were likely to show caution about taking the rand much weaker.
"The London guys got really burnt the last time they took the rand above 4.57, so they will be more careful this time."
Against the crosses the rand fell to a fresh all-time low against the pound as the British currency climbed to a one-year high against the dollar.

The rand touched a worst level of 7.2727 in afternoon dealings, but recovered slightly towards the close to last trade at 7.2561/2663. Against the mark, the rand was last seen at 0.3361/0.3366 from 0.3383/3389 previously.
On the bond market yields moved higher in quiet range-bound trading, tracking the weaker rand.
Dealers said players were sidelined ahead of the release of a raft of economic data due later this week including September consumer inflation and money supply figures.
"It's been very quiet. People are a bit anxious about the figures, although a lot of it has been discounted already," a trader said.
At 1400 GMT the key R150 bond was at 15.375 percent from 15.31 percent late on Friday following some "good bids" at the higher levels touched during the day.

According to a Reuters poll of 12 economists, the September consumer price index, due on Wednesday, will rise 8.1 percent year-on-year or 0.7 percent month-on-month after rising 7.5 percent and 0.7 percent in August.

On the money supply front economists forecast M3, due out on Friday, would grow at a slower rate of 15.1 percent in September compared with a preliminary 15.51 percent in August. The average was drawn from a range of 14.4 percent to 15.8 percent.
September trade data is also expected from Wednesday. The figure drew predictions of a 720 million rand surplus compared with a 130 million rand surplus in August.
Bond Exchange figures show foreigners bought a net 197.40 million rand worth of South African bonds on Friday after selling 168.48 million rand the previous day.
Nominal cumulative volumes were pegged at 3.69 billion rand from 33.83 billion rand on Thursday -- a settlement day.
On the money market, three-month NCDs were on Monday quoted steady at between 16.10 percent bid and 15.95 percent, while the 90-day BA rate was unchanged at between 15.55 and 15.35 percent.
The Reserve Bank indicated the daily shortage at 7.744 billion rand on Saturday from 7.754 billion rand on Friday.
-- Nicole Mordant, Johannesburg newsroom 27 11 482 1003
